Functions

 my (%not_in_next)
for my $elem (map{/^([0-9a-f]+)(.*)$/;[$1=> $2];}split(/\n/, $ARGV[2]))
$topic $not_in_next
$not_in_master exit fi exit
This sample hook safeguards
topic branches that have been
published from being rewound
The workflow assumed here
master is never merged into it 		again (either directly or indirectly).*Once a topic branch is fully cooked and merged into"master"
$topic $not_in_next
$not_in_master exit fi exit
This sample hook safeguards
topic branches that have been
published from being rewound
The workflow assumed here
master is never merged into it
it is deleted If you need to
build on top of it to correct
earlier a new topic branch is
created by forking at the tip
of the master This is not
strictly but it makes it
easier to keep your history
simple *Whenever you need to
test or publish your changes
to topic merge them into next
branch The being an hardcodes
the publish branch name to be
but it is trivial to make it
configurable via $GIT_DIR
config mechanism With this you
would want to and things that
have not been merged into
other branches can be easily
rebased without affecting
other people But once it is
you would not want to rewind 		it (2)...if a topic branch has been fully merged to"master".Then you can delete it.More importantly

Definition at line 75 of file pre-rebase.sample.

$topic $not_in_next $not_in_master exit fi exit This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been published from being rewound The workflow assumed here master is never merged into it again ( either directly or  indirectly  ) 
Type Constraints
$topic $not_in_next $not_in_master exit fi exit This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been published from being rewound The workflow assumed here master is never merged into it it is deleted If you need to build on top of it to correct earlier a new topic branch is created by forking at the tip of the master This is not strictly but it makes it easier to keep your history simple* Whenever you need to test or publish your changes to topic merge them into next branch The being an hardcodes the publish branch name to be but it is trivial to make it configurable via $GIT_DIR config mechanism With this you would want to and things that have not been merged into other branches can be easily rebased without affecting other people But once it is you would not want to rewind it ( 2   ) 
Type Constraints

publish
Initial value:
next
basebranch="$1"
if test "$#" = 2
then
    topic="refs/heads/$2"
else
    topic=`git symbolic-ref HEAD` ||
    exit 0

Definition at line 30 of file pre-rebase.sample.

fi only_next_1
Initial value:
`git rev-list ^master "^$topic" ${publish} | sort`
only_next_2=`git rev-list ^master           ${publish} | sort`
if test "$only_next_1" = "$only_next_2"
then
    not_in_topic=`git rev-list "^$topic" master`
    if test -z "$not_in_topic"
    then
        echo >&2 "$topic is already up-to-date with master"
        exit 1

Definition at line 105 of file pre-rebase.sample.

$topic $not_in_next $not_in_master exit fi exit This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been published from being rewound The workflow assumed here master is never merged into it it is deleted If you need to build on top of it to correct earlier a new topic branch is created by forking at the tip of the master This is not strictly but it makes it easier to keep your history simple* Whenever you need to test or publish your changes to topic merge them into next branch The being an hardcodes the publish branch name to be but it is trivial to make it configurable via $GIT_DIR config mechanism With this you would want to and things that have not been merged into other branches can be easily rebased without affecting other people But once it is published

Definition at line 105 of file pre-rebase.sample.

$topic $not_in_next $not_in_master exit fi exit This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been published from being rewound The workflow assumed here master is never merged into it it is deleted If you need to build on top of it to correct earlier a new topic branch is created by forking at the tip of the master This is not strictly but it makes it easier to keep your history simple* Whenever you need to test or publish your changes to topic merge them into next branch The being an hardcodes the publish branch name to be but it is trivial to make it configurable via $GIT_DIR config mechanism With this you would want to and things that have not been merged into other branches can be easily rebased without affecting other people But once it is you would not want to rewind you should not build on top of it other people may already want to change things related to the topic as patches against your master

Definition at line 129 of file pre-rebase.sample.

$topic $not_in_next $not_in_master exit fi exit This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been published from being rewound The workflow assumed here master is never merged into it it is deleted If you need to build on top of it to correct earlier a new topic branch is created by forking at the tip of the master This is not strictly but it makes it easier to keep your history simple* Whenever you need to test or publish your changes to topic merge them into next branch The being an hardcodes the publish branch name to be but it is trivial to make it configurable via $GIT_DIR config mechanism With this you would want to and things that have not been merged into other branches can be easily rebased without affecting other people But once it is you would not want to rewind you should not build on top of it other people may already want to change things related to the topic as patches against your so if you need further changes

Definition at line 129 of file pre-rebase.sample.
